p.s: In the following I am going to analyze Sonnet 60 by Shakespeare.
This sonnet is about how the time keeps running and how cruelly and fastly our life's can end.
Just like the typical sonnet by Shakespeare the Sonnet 60 can be subdivided into three quatrains and one couplet.
The first quatrain is about how fast the time is running while a very usual event, like waves coming to the beach (see l. 1) happens.
How the minutes hurry away (see l. 2) is described as toil (see l. 4).
In the second quatrain the author describes time's surprising talent (see l. 8) to make things become less important.
As an example he mentions nativity, which was the main of light (l. 5) once and foughtfaught darkness (see l. 7).
The third quatrain is about how time supports the youth's grow up (see l. 9).
On the other side it is also mentioned how everything simply exists to become eliminated by time one day (see l. 12).
In the couplet the author formulates his wish that his textestexts won't be cut down by time (see l. 13) and that he does not wanwant to stop praising your worth (l. 14).
The Sonnet 60 was written in the iambic pentameter with a cross rhyme in the three quatrains and a pair rhyme in the couplet.
To underline his message the author uses a lot of stylistic devices.
The first quatrain instantly starts with a comparison on a temporal base (see ll. 1-2).
This comparison between the running time and waves at the beach simply stresses how unstoppable and usual time goes by.
He probably uses the waves as a comparison because watching them gives us the feeling that the time stands still for a momentsmoment.
Furthermore he personificates the minutes [that] hasten (l. 2).
This rhetorical device makes the reader think, that the minutes and with that the time in genral passes so fastly on purpose.
That makes us seeing the time as the enemy.
The expression minutes hasten to their end (l. 2) is very tragically formulated.
It gives the readyreader an unsecureinsecure feeling because I think what happens after the end is a question which burdens a lot of people.
Shakespeare keeps personification the minutes and writes, that they are changing places with that which goes before (l. 3).
The process of time passing by is with that described as very stressystressful and busy.
As everybody knows, stressystressful situations are not relaxed at all which an antithesis to the waves coming at the beach (see l. 1).
Also I think that busy situations seem to us to be the shortest, as if time passes by faster.
The time passing by is also named toil (l. 4) in the sonnet.
A strong word like that effects the reader to have a negative opinion about the time in this case.
All in all Shakespeare uses the first quatrain to make the reader have a terrible opinion about time and to make them think that the time passes by to annoy us.
In the next quatrain the author mentions the Nativity [which was] once in the main of light (l. 5).
The reader gets influenced and sees the Nativity as something really glory and important.
Then there is another personification [Nativity] crawls to maturity (l. 6).
The reader now has the image of fighting Nativity.
This image gets confirmed by the verse Crooked eclipse 'gainst his glory fight (l. 7).
Then there is the metaphor, that time has a special gift (see l. 8).
The thought about the time being alive is kept here but this time the author gives a talent to the time which does not let the reader have a bad image of the time.
To somesum it up, in this quatrain Shakespeare gives an example how passing time can also trigger things that don't have to be negative.
The third quatrain starts with a personification: Time doth transfix (l. 9), again to make sure that the reader sees the time as an living individual.
Then we have a metaphor the flourish set on youth (l. 9).
The growing up youth gets compared to things in nature that have to grow.
That way he can relate to the first line in which also the nature is the comparison.
furthermore he also describes the time's scythe (l. 12) which can fastly mean the end to all living plants.
Another metaphor in line ten is parallels in beauty's brow.
He probably wants to say that every single detail becomes beautiful.
Here the author mentionesmentions clearly how the time makes the teenager become beautiful adults, which is clearly a positive aspect.
Still it is also mentioned how quickly and cruelly time can end everything.
The final couplet the lyrical I appears with the first pronoun in the sonnet: My verse shall stand.
His worry is mention, the time might also make people forget about the lyrical I's texts.
We can guess that the lyrical I is Shakespeare, because he is an author who probably doesn't want his texts to become forgiven.
By using the pronoun and show that the problem time is also about himself the author makes the reader feel with him and understand him.
Also the pronoun thy (l. 14) is mentioned.
We don't know who exactly the author adressesaddresses here.
Praising thy worth, despite his cruel hands(l. 14) shows that the author won't let the time stop him and his writings.
The last words of the expression leave an image of the time in the readersreader's mind which is very terrible in which time passes on purpose to annoy us.
To conclude it, the author hopes that his writings won't be destroyed by time.
